Projects
Youth Mental Health in the Era of a Pandemic Panel

About The Event:

The COVID-19 pandemic has pushed billions of people into unprecedented situations, forcing them to adapt both abruptly and quickly. Racism has also accentuated the mental health crisis of many BIPOC. As a result, the mental health of individuals across the globe has been significantly impacted by COVID-19, yet it is an overlooked issue. We at Detester Magazine recognize how stressful these circumstances must be for many. We will host an international open discussion in addition to a mental health guide to understand the impact of the pandemic and racial injustice on the mental health of youth.

Join our international open discussion on September 27th, 2020 at 4PM PST/ 7 PM EST to discuss how COVID-19 and racism have influenced our mental health. Meet our panelists below. They will share mental health advice and answer your questions live. Sign up for the panel to learn about ways to address mental health stigma and support mental health during this difficult time!

Sign up here!

Meet The Panelists:

Dior Vargas

Dior Vargas, MS, MPH is a Queer Latina Feminist Mental Health Activist and creator of the POC and Mental Illness Photo Project. She's the editor of The Color of My Mind, a book based on the project. Her work and insight have been covered in media outlets such as The New York Times. Dior is the recipient of numerous awards, including the Obama White House Champion of Change for Disability Advocacy.

Gia Kokotakis

"I am Gia Kokotakis, retired Team USA figure skater, author, Georgetown University student, and mental health activist. Growing up in an aesthetic sport, I faced constant pressure to maintain a low weight and thin shape that led to an eating disorder. Now two years recovered, I am sharing my story in the hopes that I can cause change in my sport and help anyone struggling with what I went through."

Hannah Blum

Hannah Blum is a writer, mental illness activist, and author of the book, ​The truth about Broken: The Unfixed Version of Self-Love. ​In 2016, she came forward about her bipolar disorder diagnosis on her blog, ​Halfway2Hannah ​recently named one of the top Blogs of 2020 ​by Healthline. Since then, she has grown her social media presence by sharing quotes, poetry, and video content that unapologetically shares her life with bipolar and opens up the conversation about the social justice issues facing people with mental illness. She has been featured in various publications, including​ Teen Vogue,​ and recently won a Telly Award for her WebMd mini docu: Dating with Bipolar. ​Hannah wants to empower those living with mental illness and work towards changing the way we perceive mental health.

Jessica Orenstein

Jessica joined JED in February 2019. Prior to joining the JED team, she worked in the field of public health workforce development for nonprofit organizations in both Los Angeles and New York City. Before gaining experience in workforce development, Jessica worked in the higher education field devoting several years to the academic, professional, and personal development of new and first-year students at Saint Louis University. Jessica grew up in the suburb of Belleville, Illinois and completed both her B.S. in Communication Sciences and Disorders and M.S. in Public Health – Behavioral Science and Health Education at Saint Louis University in St. Louis, Missouri.
